docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration summoned six drug company executives to the White House this week and reprimanded them for running advertisements critical of President Clinton's plan to offer prescription drug benefits to everyone on Medicare. In the advertisements, ''Flo,'' an arthritic Medicare beneficiary, suggests that Mr. Clinton's plan would limit the ability of doctors and patients to select the best medicines. The spots recall a scathing debate in 1993 and 1994, when the insurance industry conducted an advertising campaign to kill Mr. Clinton's plan for universal health insurance.

headline.main: Drug Makers Are Taken to Task for Criticism of Clinton Plan

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration summons six drug company execs to White House this week and reprimands them for running advertisements critical of Pres Clinton's plan to offer prescription drug benefits to everyone on Medicare; six companies that send representatives to meeting are Genentech, Genzyme, Eli Lilly, Merck, Pharmacia & Upjohn and Warner-Lambert (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Theater NINO NADA THEATER FESTIVAL. ''The Dancing Handkerchief,'' about an apprentice to a temperamental and inept sorcerer, presented by Flying Carpet. The production features mime, music, puppets, masks and a whimsical handkerchief, tomorrow and Sunday at 3 P.M. at Nada 45, 445 West 45th Street, fourth floor, Clinton. ''Feet Water,'' a parable about cleanliness adapted from an Irish folk tale, presented by Attic Salt Theater Company, featuring masks, puppets and audience participation, Saturdays and Sundays at 2 P.M. (through Oct. 3), at Pink Pony, 178 Ludlow Street, Lower East Side. ''The Sultan's Wife,'' a music and comedy production adapted from a Swahili folk tale, also presented by Attic company, Saturdays and Sundays at 2 P.M., at Pink Pony. Tickets: $9 for each show. Information: (212) 269-4849.

docs.lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives approved legislation today that would make it difficult, if not impossible, to bring large class-action lawsuits against tobacco companies, gun makers and a wide variety of other businesses. The legislation was supported by many major industries, from automobile and chemical producers to small aircraft makers and insurance companies.

headline.main: HOUSE PASSES BILL THAT WOULD LIMIT CLASS-ACTION SUITS

docs.abstract: House of Representatives approves legislation that would make it difficult, if not impossible, to bring large class-action lawsuits against tobacco companies, gun makers and wide variety of other businesses; legislation is supported by many major industries, from automobile and chemical producers to small aircraft makers and insurance companies; it would require state court judges, who have often been more sympathetic to plaintiffs in such suits, to transfer most of their class-action lawsuits to Federal courts; Federal rules on class-action lawsuits are often more stringent than state court procedures, and Federal courts have limited some kinds of class actions entertained by state judges; as result, plaintiffs' lawyers have been making greater and more successful use of state courts in recent years (M)
docs.snippet: The House of Representatives approved legislation today that would make it difficult, if not impossible, to bring large class-action lawsuits against tobacco companies, gun makers and a wide variety of other businesses.    The legislation was...

docs.lead_paragraph: IS a flawed experiment in redesigning Medicare better than no experiment at all? No, says Karen Ignagni, who represents managed care plans that are fighting to block demonstrations intended to foster competition. The problem, she says, is that the demonstrations, scheduled to begin in 2001, ''leave out the Government's fee-for-service plan, tilting competition unfairly against private plans.''

headline.main: Economic Scene; Rebates could smooth the way for a Medicare reform plan.

docs.abstract: Michael M Weinstein (Economic Scene) column on reforming Medicare; focuses on disputes over demonstrations intended to foster competition that are scheduled to begin in 2001; Karen Ignagni, who represents managed care plans that are fighting to block demonstrations, says demonstrations leave out Government's fee-for-service plan, tilting competition unfairly against private plans; Len Nichols, economist at Urban Institute and member of committee of independent experts that designed demonstrations, disagrees; committee has decided to ask Congress to allow plans to offer rebates--in form of lower monthly Medicare premiums; rebates can provide powerful recruiting tools and perhaps give beneficiaries in demonstration sites something tangible if demonstrations go forward; rebates to enrollees lies at heart of Pres Clinton's plan as well as plan proposed by Sen John Breaux and Repr Bill Thomas; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Philip N. Brownstein, a top Federal housing administrator in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations who fought discrimination by builders and landlords and who expanded Depression-era housing laws to widen home ownership among minority groups, died on Friday in a hospital in Silver Spring, Md. He was 82. In 1963, Mr. Brownstein was named commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration, which became part of the Department of Housing and Urban Development when the department was created in 1965. He continued to serve as F.H.A. commissioner and as Assistant Secretary for Housing in the new agency. Under his leadership, Federal housing policy broadened its reach to include previously forgotten groups.

headline.main: Philip Brownstein, Federal Housing Advocate, Dies at 82

docs.abstract: Philip N Brownstein, top Federal housing administrator in Kennedy and Johnson Administrations who fought discrimination by builders and landlords, dies at age of 82; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation, the giant health insurance and financial services company based in Philadelphia, said yesterday that it had increased its stock-repurchase program by $2 billion. Since the start of the year, Cigna has repurchased 17.1 million shares of stock at a cost of $1.5 billion. A further $2 billion buyback would represent 11 percent of the company's $17.8 billion market capitalization. Companies use buybacks to increase earnings per share by reducing the number of shares outstanding.

headline.main: CIGNA BOLSTERS STOCK-BUYBACK PLAN BY $2 BILLION

docs.lead_paragraph: A state sells its driver's license records to a stalker; he selects his victim -- a Hollywood starlet -- from the photos and murders her. A telephone company sells a list of calls; an extortionist analyzes the pattern of calls and blackmails the owner of the phone.
docs.abstract: William Safire Op-Ed column supports law that would require state or business to request permission of individual customers before selling their names to practitioners of 'target marketing' (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HANS PETER BRONDMO is building an Internet company squarely astride the most bitter cultural divide in the on-line world -- the war over privacy and E-mail spam. There is possibly no more bitter issue for most Net-smart computer users and Web surfers than the tidal wave of digital junk mail -- known as spam -- that has accompanied the explosion of electronic commerce.

headline.main: Converting E-Mail From Spam to Steak

docs.abstract: Interview with Hans Peter Brondmo, founder of Post Communications, Internet company that provides clients with customized marketing programs based on software tools that blend traditional database marketing with E-mail focused on specific consumers; he holds it is possible to honor Internet's cultural values of privacy and user control while using powerful server computers to identify specific customer preferences; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Another leap in the United States trade deficit in July fueled fears today that the continuing surge in imports was threatening the health of the dollar. As the American currency dipped yet again versus the Japanese yen, largely because of disappointment over the widening trade gap at home and inaction by monetary authorities in Tokyo, stocks and bonds reacted by falling sharply in financial markets. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 225 points, slightly more than 2 percent. [Page C10.]

headline.main: TRADE DEFICIT RISE PROVOKES CONCERN OF RISK TO DOLLAR

docs.abstract: Commerce Dept reports that US trade deficit in July hit $25.2 billion, higher than June imbalance of $24.6 billion, confounding expectations that deficit would start to shrink as economic growth picked up around world; imports from China, Western Europe and Japan hit new highs, but exports advanced only slightly; leap in US trade deficit fuels fears that continuing surge in imports is threatening health of dollar; stocks and bonds react by falling sharply in financial markets as US currency dips yet again versus Japanese yen; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NOW that the big pharmacy chains seem to have built facing drugstores at every intersection in America, the competition to sell aspirin, shampoo and antibiotics is moving onto the Internet just as aggressively. The idea has a lot going for it. From a practical standpoint, drugstore products are easy to ship. A pile of toiletries fits neatly in a relatively small package. And even the fruitiest of shampoos are nonperishable.

headline.main: Drugstores Scramble to Find Choice Corners in Cyberspace

docs.abstract: Lisa Prevost article on aggressive competition among Internet-based drugstore chains; on-line pharmacies can make it easier than ever to refill prescription or shop around for best deal in over-the-counter remedies; are finding it hard to win needed contracts with companies that manage prescription benefits for health insurance plans because of turf battles over mail-order prescriptions; some pharmacy benefit managers are moving ahead with own on-line pharmacies; photos (M)
docs.snippet: NOW that the big pharmacy chains seem to have built facing drugstores at every intersection in America, the competition to sell aspirin, shampoo and antibiotics is moving onto the Internet just as aggressively.    The idea has a lot going for it....
